projectPurpose: To provide a fast, efficient, and user-friendly command-line tool specifically designed for viewing and navigating through CSV files directly within the terminal, similar to how the `less` command is used for general text files.
mainFeatures: Efficient handling of CSV structure (delimiters, quoting)

alternatives.name: VisiData
mainFeatures: Supports multiple tabular formats (CSV, TSV, JSON, Excel, etc.)

alternatives.name: qsv
mainFeatures: Wide range of data manipulation commands
Supports multiple file formats (CSV, JSON, Parquet, Excel, etc.)

alternatives.name: csvkit
mainFeatures: Suite of command-line utilities for CSV
Convert to and from various formats (JSON, SQL, Excel)
Filtering, sorting, and joining CSV files
Perform SQL queries on CSV data

alternatives.name: Miller (mlr)
mainFeatures: Processes various formats (CSV, TSV, JSON, etc.)
Provides verbs for data manipulation (sort, cut, filter)
Efficient for large files by streaming data

alternatives.name: Tad
mainFeatures: Fast viewer for large CSV files
Filtering and sorting without full data load

alternatives.name: Modern CSV
mainFeatures: Fast loading of large CSV files

marketPositioning: csvlens is positioned as a lightweight, fast, and dedicated command-line *viewer* for CSV files, offering a `less`-like experience tailored for tabular data. It focuses on efficiently displaying and navigating CSVs directly in the terminal, particularly useful for large files where full loading in other applications might be slow. While alternatives like qsv and csvkit offer broader data manipulation, csvlens specializes in the viewing aspect, providing a simple yet powerful way to inspect CSV content using familiar terminal commands and leveraging Rust for performance.
